#Text=[0033] Because the sensor is not particularly selective, it is most suitable for the detection of an individual gas.

#Text=It could be, for example, an automobile carbon-dioxide sensor--in the future perhaps a hydrogen sensor, if the use of hydrogen becomes widespread in automobiles--or as a gas detector in buildings or industry.
#Text=The sensor is particularly suitable as a leak sensor in valves.
#Text=This is because a valve controls a known gas and the sensor can be located close to the valve in a closed space, where the content of the gas prior to the leak is nearly unchanging.
#Text=In this application, simultaneous temperature measurement will be sufficient to compensate for errors.
#Text=Of course, the sensor can act as part of a sensor system, in which a few gases are measured specifically and a missing gas can be detected using the method described.
#Text=In a gas sensor, the upper diaphragm can be made very stiff and heavy and thus the ultrasound can be made to reflect well from the under surface of the diaphragm.
#Text=For example, a SOI-based cavity is highly suitable for this purpose.
#Text=In connection with a gas sensor, we use the name the UtraGas or the UtraGas Sensor.
#Text=2.4 Pressure Sensor
#Text=[0034] If the sensor is used for measuring pressure, the cavity should be filled with a known gas.
#Text=Preferably with a gas with low sound damping and which causes a small effective capacitance and large inductance.
#Text=Of course, the gas should also be selected so that it will not easily react with silicon or silicon oxide, and will not easily diffuse out of the cavity.

#Text=A problem with existing MEMS pressure sensors is that the spring constant must be dimensioned in such a way that the height of the cavity will be sufficiently stiff for the maximum pressure not to cause excessive deflection in the diaphragm.
#Text=The height of the cavity must be kept low, so that capacitive measurement can be made using a low voltage, while the resolution nevertheless remains sufficient.
#Text=In the UtraSensor this problem does not appear.
#Text=In other words, by dimensioning the diaphragm to be slack, we increase sensitivity and thus make the device less sensitive to, for example, problems arising from torsion in the substrate.
#Text=Of course, the downside is that the UltraSensor's effective spring constant depends to some extent on the pressure, according to the following equation
#Text=k = k m + p A h ##EQU00001##
#Text=in which h is the height of the cavity, p the pressure, and A the cross-sectional area of the cavity.
#Text=By substituting typical values in the equation, it will be noticed that, when the height is 100 .mu.m or greater, the mechanical spring constant determines the effective spring constant.
#Text=Thus, the pressure dependence of the spring constant does not cause any great problem.
